citations.narrative:
The licensee did not have the required records on the acquisition or disposition of two Aoudad that were bought at an
acution in MO April 6, 2023 and of a Dingo that was received from a zoo in MI on December 6, 2023. Both of these
acquistions were found on health certificates from IL and MO by the inspector during a records review at the State of IL
Department of Agriculture. When asked for the acquisition/disposition records of the Aoudad sales, the licensee initially
denied having bought any Aoudad until inspectors produced the State of MO health certificate of the purchase listed along
with multiple zebu. After looking at the record inspectors' produced, the licensee advised that he didn’t keep any records
on them and that they were sent to someone else. When asked for the information of where the Audads were sent, the
licensee stated that he did not want to provide the information to inspectors.
A request to look at the records of the zebu and mini cows that the licensee bred and sold were also denied. The
licensee stated that the hoofstock, including the Aoudad were only being sold for food/fiber and that he did not have to
provide any records to inspectors to prove it. Inspectors were unable to determine regulated vs unregualated activity with
the exotic hoofstock due to the refusal to see any records. The sale/transport of a dingo is an exotic speicies that would
require the acquistion and disposition records by the licensee which was also refused upon request.
The lack of complete acquisition and disposition records does not provide for proper traceability of the regulated animals.
The refusal to allow inspectors to look at records makes it impossible to determine if there is regulated activity vs non-
regulated activity being conducted with animal species that are usually utilized in a regulated manner.
Every dealer and exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following
information concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or
otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise
disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
WILLIAM HEINE, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee did not have the required records on the acquisition or disposition of two Aoudad that were bought at an 
acution in MO April 6, 2023 and of a Dingo that was received from a zoo in MI on December 6, 2023. Both of these 
acquistions were found on health certificates from IL and MO by the inspector during a records review at the State of IL 
Department of Agriculture. When asked for the acquisition/disposition records of the Aoudad sales, the licensee initially 
denied having bought any Aoudad until inspectors produced the State of MO health certificate of the purchase listed along 
with multiple zebu. After looking at the record inspectors' produced, the licensee advised that he didn’t keep any records 
on them and that they were sent to someone else. When asked for the information of where the Audads were sent, the 
licensee stated that he did not want to provide the information to inspectors. 
 
 A request to look at the records of the zebu and mini cows that the licensee bred and sold were also denied. The 
licensee stated that the hoofstock, including the Aoudad were only being sold for food/fiber and that he did not have to 
provide any records to inspectors to prove it. Inspectors were unable to determine regulated vs unregualated activity with 
the exotic hoofstock due to the refusal to see any records. The sale/transport of a dingo is an exotic speicies that would 
require the acquistion and disposition records by the licensee which was also refused upon request. 
 
The lack of complete acquisition and disposition records does not provide for proper traceability of the regulated animals. 
The refusal to allow inspectors to look at records makes it impossible to determine if there is regulated activity vs non-
regulated activity being conducted with animal species that are usually utilized in a regulated manner. 
 
Every dealer and exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following 
information concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or 
otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise 
disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.

Additional Inspectors: 
WILLIAM HEINE, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
